pull.title: init, test: improve network reachability test coverage and safety
pull.body:
Adds missing network reachability test coverage and an assertion during init, noticed while reviewing #22834:

- assert during init that each network reachability is  true by default
- add CJDNS to the `LimitedAndReachable_Network` unit tests
- hoist proxy out of two network loops in feature_proxy.py
- test that passing invalid `-proxy` raises expected init error
- test that passing invalid `-onion` raises expected init error
- test that passing `-onlynet=onion` without `-proxy` and `-onion` raises expected init error
- test that passing `-onlynet=onion` with `-onion=0` and with `-noonion` raises expected init error

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#23531](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23531) (Add Yggdrasil support by prusnak)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
Note, this pull has a trivial one-line test conflict with #22834 that IMO should be reviewed/merged first so this pull doesn't invalidate the review there.

verification.payload:
tree 9e3b323e0e86167e350ee3efa0eed56ba9b5f87d
parent 848b11615b67a3c49f76ebbcaa241a322d8014d8
author Jon Atack <jon@atack.com> 1643579185 +0100
committer Jon Atack <jon@atack.com> 1646164998 +0100

net, init: assert each network reachability is true by default

The default network reachability values are implicitly set
by this line in net.cpp:

static bool vfLimited[NET_MAX] GUARDED_BY(g_maplocalhost_mutex) = {};

This commit asserts that each network is reachable during
the first loop through them during bitcoind init.

events.message:
net, init: assert each network reachability is true by default

The default network reachability values are implicitly set
by this line in net.cpp:

static bool vfLimited[NET_MAX] GUARDED_BY(g_maplocalhost_mutex) = {};

This commit asserts that each network is reachable during
the first loop through them during bitcoind init.

rename.from: net, init, test: network reachability testing and safety improvements
rename.to: init, test: improve network reachability test coverage and safety

events.body:
ACK 58a14795b89a6bd812e0b71cb8b3088b8ab55c11

Checked the following init errors are now covered in functional tests:
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/91d12344b1e51809c1ef6b630b631a6da00267c3/src/init.cpp#L1333
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/91d12344b1e51809c1ef6b630b631a6da00267c3/src/init.cpp#L1352
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/91d12344b1e51809c1ef6b630b631a6da00267c3/src/init.cpp#L1363

Code looks great for both tests. Just ran them several times and got no error.
I think this has been ready for a few weeks now, if anyone would like to do a final review or merge.

Code Review ACK 58a14795b89a6bd812e0b71cb8b3088b8ab55c11

Change seems straightforward. Had to convince myself of the `assert` in `src/init.cpp`, but it seems right that we don't want users to specify `-onlynet=foo` and `foo` be somehow default disabled, and now `bitcoind` is silently operating without `foo`.

Post-merge ACK 58a14795b89a6bd812e0b71cb8b3088b8ab55c11

Built on MacOS Big Sur, reviewed code changes and checked the functional test was covering the errors in the PR description.

comments.body:
please convert this c-style cast to a static_cast, since you are touching the line below
```suggestion
            enum Network net = static_cast<enum Network>(n);
```
Thanks, but this is unrelated to the changes here and I prefer to not touch it.

nit: "only through network"... hmm, what about making connections **to** IPv4 addresses **through** the Tor network? Could this be misinterpreted as "onlynet=onion will also make connections to IPv4 as long as it is through Tor"?

Is "only **to** network" better wording?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -305,6 +308,32 @@ def networks_dict(d):
         assert_equal(n4['i2p']['reachable'], False)
         assert_equal(n4['cjdns']['reachable'], True)
 
+        self.stop_node(1)
+
+        self.log.info("Test passing invalid -proxy raises expected init error")
+        self.nodes[1].extra_args = ["-proxy=abc:def"]
+        msg = "Error: Invalid -proxy address or hostname: 'abc:def'"
+        self.nodes[1].assert_start_raises_init_error(expected_msg=msg)
+
+        self.log.info("Test passing invalid -onion raises expected init error")
+        self.nodes[1].extra_args = ["-onion=xyz:123"]
+        msg = "Error: Invalid -onion address or hostname: 'xyz:123'"
comments.body: `xyz:123` could be valid if `xyz` resolves. For example, `echo "127.0.0.1 xyz" >> /etc/hosts` bricks the test. Better use non-numeric port like in the `-proxy` test.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -263,12 +267,13 @@ def networks_dict(d):
 
         n2 = networks_dict(self.nodes[2].getnetworkinfo())
         assert_equal(NETWORKS, n2.keys())
+        proxy = f'{self.conf2.addr[0]}:{self.conf2.addr[1]}'
         for net in NETWORKS:
             if net == NET_I2P:
                 expected_proxy = ''
                 expected_randomize = False
             else:
-                expected_proxy = f'{self.conf2.addr[0]}:{self.conf2.addr[1]}'
+                expected_proxy = proxy
comments.body: nit: this change looks unnecessary because the expression is used just once, so putting it in a variable does not make it more maintainable. It maybe makes it less readable because now one has to visually go up a few lines in order to find what `expected_proxy` ends up with.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -279,11 +284,9 @@ def networks_dict(d):
         if self.have_ipv6:
             n3 = networks_dict(self.nodes[3].getnetworkinfo())
             assert_equal(NETWORKS, n3.keys())
+            proxy = f'[{self.conf3.addr[0]}]:{self.conf3.addr[1]}'
             for net in NETWORKS:
-                if net == NET_I2P or net == NET_ONION:
-                    expected_proxy = ''
-                else:
-                    expected_proxy = f'[{self.conf3.addr[0]}]:{self.conf3.addr[1]}'
+                expected_proxy = '' if net == NET_I2P or net == NET_ONION else proxy
comments.body:
nit: this looks unnecessary coz the expression is used just once. Also, personally, I find the perl-style harder to read: `x=1 if some_condition else 2`.

I am fine as it is, but I will be happier if commit `test: hoist proxy out of 2 network loops in feature_proxy.py` is removed :)

comments.body: I'm going to propose this documentation in another pull for potential backport to v23 if it doesn't make the branch-off (and drop it here); will look at adding your suggestion there.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -263,12 +267,13 @@ def networks_dict(d):
 
         n2 = networks_dict(self.nodes[2].getnetworkinfo())
         assert_equal(NETWORKS, n2.keys())
+        proxy = f'{self.conf2.addr[0]}:{self.conf2.addr[1]}'
         for net in NETWORKS:
             if net == NET_I2P:
                 expected_proxy = ''
                 expected_randomize = False
             else:
-                expected_proxy = f'{self.conf2.addr[0]}:{self.conf2.addr[1]}'
+                expected_proxy = proxy
comments.body: This line is invoked 4 times in the loop, so it seems better to do the more complex lookups and string interpolation before entering it (I would be surprised if Python is auto-optimising this as it's an interpreted language).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -279,11 +284,9 @@ def networks_dict(d):
         if self.have_ipv6:
             n3 = networks_dict(self.nodes[3].getnetworkinfo())
             assert_equal(NETWORKS, n3.keys())
+            proxy = f'[{self.conf3.addr[0]}]:{self.conf3.addr[1]}'
             for net in NETWORKS:
-                if net == NET_I2P or net == NET_ONION:
-                    expected_proxy = ''
-                else:
-                    expected_proxy = f'[{self.conf3.addr[0]}]:{self.conf3.addr[1]}'
+                expected_proxy = '' if net == NET_I2P or net == NET_ONION else proxy
comments.body: The more complex lookups and string interpolation are currently invoked three times in the loop, so it seems better to do them once before entering it. The ternary is used frequently in our Python tests and I think it's more succinct here to use the ternary form for an assignment instead of if - else with two assignments.

comments.body:
> nit: "only through network"... hmm, what about making connections **to** IPv4 addresses **through** the Tor network? Could this be misinterpreted as "onlynet=onion will also make connections to IPv4 as long as it is through Tor"?
> 
> Is "only **to** network" better wording?

Agreed.
and we already use "to" here in doc/tor.md and doc/i2p.md, so good call.
